newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Sri Lanka sugar import dependence seen persisting.
newsitem.headline: Sri Lanka sugar import dependence seen persisting.

text.p: Sri Lanka is expected to remain dependent on sugar imports for the forseeable future, an industry official said on Wednesday.

"It is quite evident that Sri Lanka may not achieve the national demand of sugar," N.V.T.A. Weragoda, chairman of the Sugarcane Research Institute of Sri Lanka told an international sugar conference on the tourist island of Bali.
"As a result, Sri Lanka would be one of the permanent markets for countries producing sugar for exports," he said.
He said production totalled 71,416 tonnes in 1995, down from 72,275 tonnes in 1994. Imports totalled 416,909 tonnes and 491,000 tonnes in the respective years.
Weragoda said per capita consumption had increased to 24.8 kgs in 1995 from 18.2 kgs in 1984 and a mere 4.6 kgs in 1974.
He said the high cost of setting up new factories and the limited availability of suitable land for sugarcane cultivation was a hindrance to expansion of the sector.
He said the government was seeking foreign investment in the sugar sector, adding that some companies had shown interest.
